data.title: Wall Street begins buying altcoins
data.description:
Author: thedefinvestor Translator: Shan Ouba, Jinse Finance

Leaving aside price movements, some very noteworthy changes are currently taking place in the crypto market.

Some of the world's top asset management firms have begun buying DeFi tokens this month: BlackRock purchased an undisclosed number of UNI tokens after launching its tokenized fund BUIDL on Uniswap. Apollo Global Management announced it will acquire up to 90 million MORPHO tokens (worth approximately $170 million) over the next 48 months. Citadel Securities and Ark Capital have invested in LayerZero's ZRO tokens. This marks the first time several large traditional financial institutions have included DeFi tokens in their portfolios. In addition, several weeks ago, Jupiter received a $35 million JUP investment from ParaFi Capital at spot prices. This was unheard of a few years ago. The reality is that in the past, most venture capitalists bought tokens at huge off-exchange discounts and sold them immediately after unlocking. But now, some institutions/venture capitalists are willing to buy DeFi tokens directly at market prices, which is a very positive long-term signal. Why is all this important? The buying of altcoins by top global institutions could put significant buying pressure on some high-quality altcoins, just as Bitcoin experienced in the past two years. More importantly, this could legitimize the entire industry and potentially persuade a large number of retail investors who were previously skeptical of altcoins to enter the market. Coupled with the recent buyback mechanisms launched by most mainstream dApps, this may be the condition needed for altcoins to make a strong comeback in the next cycle. I know that most people have completely lost faith in altcoins, which is often understandable. Frankly speaking, the tokens of the vast majority of projects in this field will never reach new all-time highs again. But at the same time, I firmly believe that projects with strong fundamentals may still experience huge gains in the next bull market, allowing us to witness a true "altcoin season" again. It was precisely because of institutional investment that Bitcoin rose from $16,000 to $124,000 in this round. Altcoins, on the other hand, require much less buying power to pump their price. What can we expect next? What are my plans? I believe what we're seeing now is just the beginning. BlackRock, which recently bought UNI, has historically been a trendsetter. Its actions often sway the entire financial industry. I expect more institutions to announce altcoin purchases in the coming months. That said, I don't think it's necessary to rush into buying altcoins now. Even with institutional inflows, altcoins are unlikely to perform well until Bitcoin hits the bottom of this cycle. Historically, Bitcoin bottoms typically occur a year after the cycle peak, around October. Considering the current macroeconomic environment, I wouldn't be surprised if history repeats itself and Bitcoin bottoms out in late Q3/early Q4 of 2026. Historically, March 2026 could be a good month for the crypto market, but even if a rebound occurs, I believe it will only last a few weeks. Based on the above assessment, my current plan is to significantly increase my allocation to altcoins and Bitcoin starting at the end of Q3 2026. Before that, I will only engage in dollar-cost averaging (DCA) when Bitcoin reaches key support levels. Which altcoins do I plan to buy? There's still plenty of time until Q3, but I'm mainly focusing on the following criteria: Low P/E ratio: Fully diluted token valuation / annual revenue (below 15x is excellent) High circulating supply, low inflation release A buyback mechanism or other design that brings real value to the token The team is still developing rapidly even in a bear market True product-market fit: The product is used because it's high-quality, not just for mining tokens Frankly, there aren't many projects that meet these criteria, but they are the most likely to attract institutional investors. The projects I'm currently watching include: Fluid, Jupiter, AAVE, Pendle, Hyperliquid, Lighter, EtherFi, and Sky. I may publicly disclose specific purchase plans closer to Q3. This cycle has already shown how institutions are legitimizing Bitcoin. Now, they are starting to legitimize altcoins by investing real money. As the crypto market enters an era dominated by institutions, I believe that large institutional buying of altcoins will be a significant catalyst for the next bull market. The bear market may not be over yet, but I have no doubt that a new bull market will eventually arrive. Please ensure you are prepared to position yourself.

data.title: From the Terra crash to the Indian ban, what did Jane Street do?
data.description:
Deng Tong, Jinse Finance

On February 23, 2026, Terraform sued Jane Street for alleged insider trading. The lawsuit alleges that Jane Street used insider information to withdraw funds before Terraform's collapse. The lawsuit also alleges that a Jane Street employee created a secret group chat to leak information. Jane Street called the lawsuit "a desperate gamble" and "a blatant attempt to make money."

Why did Terraform and India sue Jane Street? Did Jane Street orchestrate the 10 AM crash? What was Jane Street's profit-making logic? Did Jane Street trigger the bear market?

I. Did Jane Street cause the Terra Luna collapse?

The lawsuit was filed by Todd Snyder, the administrator in charge of Terraform's bankruptcy liquidation plan. The defendants include Jane Street Group, Jane Street Capital, co-founder Robert Granieri, and two employees: Bryce Pratt and Michael Huang. The lawsuit documents describe a channel that allowed material non-public information to be passed directly from the Terraform team to Jane Street's trading department.

According to the indictment, Pratt interned at Terraform Labs in the summer of 2021 and joined Jane Street in September of the same year. By February 2022, he had created a group chat called ‚ÄúBryce‚Äôs Secret,‚Äù which included a Terraform software engineer and members of the Terraform business development team. A chat log cited in the indictment shows the Terraform engineer writing, ‚ÄúBro, we all know who the buyer is. It‚Äôs where you work‚Ä¶ Jane Street.‚Äù When asked whether Jane Street‚Äôs handling of this information was legal, Pratt allegedly responded, ‚ÄúEverything. Maybe. If Jump can do something legally, we probably can too.‚Äù The core allegation in the complaint concerns May 7, 2022. On that day, Terraform withdrew 150 million UST from the decentralized exchange Curve3pool as part of an unannounced liquidity migration plan. Within 10 minutes, a wallet associated with Jane Street withdrew 85 million UST from the same pool, the largest single transaction ever processed on the platform. These two withdrawals caused UST liquidity instability. Within a week, the Terra Luna ecosystem collapsed, wiping out approximately $40 billion in market value, and Terraform also crashed. However, the market generally believes that UST's algorithmic stabilization mechanism itself has structural vulnerabilities, and whether a single liquidity fluctuation was sufficient to cause a systemic collapse remains controversial. According to the lawsuit, this transaction "could not have been completed without insider information." Jane Street responded that the losses were caused by "billions of dollars in fraud perpetrated by Terraform Labs management." Terraform founder Do Kwon was sentenced to 15 years in prison in December 2025 for wire fraud and conspiracy. Another $4 billion lawsuit filed in December of the same year accused Jump Trading of participating in a secret transaction: buying Luna at $0.40, while the market price at the time was $110. The indictment has been heavily redacted. Specific profit data, internal communication records, and details of Jane Street's trading strategies have been sealed. The case contains 13 charges involving insider trading, securities fraud, violation of the Commodity Exchange Act, unjust enrichment, and breach of confidentiality. II. Why did India ban Jane Street? In early July 2025, the Securities and Exchange Commission of India (SEBI) issued a temporary injunction against four Jane Street entities (JSI Investments, JSI2 Investments, Jane Street Singapore, and Jane Street Asia Trading), prohibiting them from entering the Indian securities market. This 105-page injunction alleges that Jane Street manipulated the BANKNIFTY and NIFTY 50 indices on 18 derivative expiry dates between January 2023 and March 2025. SEBI calculated that its illegal profits totaled 365.02 billion rupees, approximately $4.3 billion. The regulator described a two-stage strategy known as the "expiration date trap." During the morning trading session, Jane Street's firms would aggressively buy index stocks and futures, typically accounting for over 20% of individual stock market trading volume, thus driving up the index. In the afternoon, they would reverse course, selling their positions, causing the index to fall. The short option positions established in the morning would profit as the index declined. On January 17, 2024, they profited 7.35 billion rupees. The Securities and Exchange Commission of India (SEBI) described these trades as ‚Äúviolent, large, and aggressive,‚Äù creating a ‚Äúfalse or misleading illusion of market activity.‚Äù In February 2025, the National Stock Exchange of India (NSE) issued a written warning to Jane Street, demanding it cease such activities. Despite receiving the warning, the company continued the same trading. The SEBI called this behavior ‚Äúserious and a blatant disregard/defeat of explicit warnings.‚Äù Jane Street dismissed the SEBI's investigation, calling it ‚Äúbiased‚Äù and ‚Äúpre-set.‚Äù The company appealed to the Securities and Exchange Commission of India. The hearing was postponed on February 25, 2026, the same week Terraform filed a lawsuit in New York. SEBI seized 48.4357 billion rupees (approximately $566 million) in alleged illicit proceeds.

III. Did Jane Street orchestrate the 10 AM crash?

Several market observers, including prominent cryptocurrency figure Justin Bechler, believe that Jane Street's holdings in the BlackRock iShares Bitcoin Trust ETF (IBIT) may have concealed its net short Bitcoin position through undisclosed hedging operations. Bechler points out that Jane Street manipulated Bitcoin prices by algorithmically coordinating Bitcoin sell-offs daily at 10 AM Eastern Time.

Recent 13-F filings show that as of the fourth quarter of 2025, Jane Street held approximately $790 million worth of IBIT stock.

Jan Happel and Yann Allemann, co-founders of blockchain analytics firm Glassnode, also documented these patterns through their shared X account, Negentropic, stating, "The 10 AM Bitcoin crash miraculously disappeared after the Jane Street lawsuit went public." Onchain analyst Nonzee posted a Bitcoin hourly chart on Wednesday, claiming that Jane Street had been "manipulating" the market during that period for months. Cryptocurrency market watchdog Whale Factor claimed that Bitcoin experienced a sustained 2% to 3% daily drop within minutes of the US market opening and accused programmatic manipulation of the issue since early November. ‚ÄúMany traders believe that Jane Street‚Äôs massive position of over $2.5 billion in BlackRock IBIT may be the main driver: artificially manipulating liquidity to buy the spot ETF at a discount.‚Äù Macro analyst Alex Kr√ºger disagrees with this claim, sharing blockchain data showing that Bitcoin has accumulated a 0.9% return in the 10:00-10:30 AM window since January 1st, and claims this is not a ‚Äúsystemic sell-off.‚Äù ‚ÄúEveryone says Bitcoin crashes every day at 10:00 AM. I looked at the data and found that‚Äôs not the case.‚Äù The ‚Äú10:00 AM crash‚Äù theory is a widely used risk asset repricing mechanism that is closely correlated with the price performance of the Nasdaq stock index. IV. Jane Street‚Äôs Profit-Making Logic: Privileged Status The Terraform case alleges that the defendants used insider information to trade, while the Securities and Exchange Commission of India (SEBI) order describes market manipulation through trading patterns. Both cases reveal a similar structural logic: leveraging privileged positions to influence the market and then profiting from derivatives trading. According to allegations by the Securities and Exchange Commission of India (SEBI), Jane Street profited from short option positions in India by manipulating index stock prices. In the cryptocurrency space, complaints allege that Jane Street used insider information about Terraform liquidity withdrawals to close positions before the crash. At the heart of both cases, the allegations are that Jane Street possessed informational or channel advantages that ordinary market participants lacked. V. Did Jane Street Trigger the Bear Market? Jane Street Triggers the Bear Market Posts circulating on forums claim that Bitcoin rose by approximately 10% in two days, coinciding with the disappearance of the so-called intraday selling pattern, suggesting that the legal action against Jane Street altered market behavior.

Jane Street Did Not Trigger the Bear Market

  • AllianceDAO co-founder @QwQiao posted: People have spent months looking for scapegoats for the Bitcoin bear market (such as Jane Street, Quantum, software sell-offs, etc.), but ultimately, as an asset without a cash flow anchor, the main driver of Bitcoin's price movement is simply "technical analysis (TA)," which is essentially psychology. More people believe in the four-year cycle than the five-year cycle. Once a trend breaks, people start taking profits or cutting losses. Most other explanations seem more correlated than causal. Now, we just need to patiently wait for the mass psychology to completely capitulate (which may have already happened) and for the trend to reverse, which doesn't necessarily need a catalyst.

  • Yale ReiSoleil, CTO of Ethereum financial infrastructure company Untrading: "No company sits in front of a terminal and presses the 'sell Bitcoin' button. But Bitcoin's very structure‚Äîthe ETF structure, AP exemption, the shift to physical creation‚Äîcreates a gray area where price discovery can be suppressed without anyone breaking the rules."

  • Nick Puckrin, co-founder and chief market analyst of education platform Coin Bureau: "Whether there is market manipulation or not, Bitcoin's price is not driven by just one company, no matter how influential that company is. It's not a meme. Understandably, investors who are confident in Bitcoin will look for scapegoats when the market crashes. But the reality of Bitcoin market dynamics is much more complex." Puckrin believes that Bitcoin's recent weakness is best explained by geopolitical uncertainty, global liquidity conditions, and competition for investor attention from the rapidly growing artificial intelligence industry.

  • Bitcoin futures trader @traderamericano believes: All this noise makes it seem like Jane Street is the only market maker.

    • They're not the only trading firm. I can accept insider trading... but to put all the blame for Bitcoin's decline on them... is going too far.

Conclusion

Jane Street is currently in the eye of the storm.

Currently, regulators and courts have not found Jane Street responsible for any major cryptocurrency crashes. The Terraform case may clarify whether Jane Street's trading activities crossed legal boundaries or reflected standard market-making practices. This outcome may also influence how the judiciary interprets insider information in decentralized markets.

Both lawsuits and injunctions raise the same question: when a quantitative giant with technological, financial, and informational advantages is deeply embedded in the market structure, is its highly structured profit model what modern finance should look like?

data.title: When Block laid off half the company, there were no bad guys in the AI ‚Äã‚Äãunemployment wave.
data.description:
Author: Yellow Lobster, Deep Tide TechFlow¬†

On February 22nd, an article titled "The 2028 Global Intelligent Crisis" went viral in the financial world. The author, Citrini Research, a macro research firm, presented the article as a "memorandum from the future," setting the timeline to June 2028 and reviewing how this AI-triggered economic crisis gradually evolved into a systemic collapse.

One ‚Äã‚Äãsentence in the article stated, "In early 2026, the first wave of layoffs triggered by the replacement of human intelligence began. Profits expanded, earnings exceeded expectations, and stock prices hit record highs."

Four days later, this statement was no longer a thought experiment.

On February 26th, Jack Dorsey posted on X: "we're making @blocks smaller today." Block, the fintech company that owns Square and Cash App, released its fourth-quarter earnings report that day. Gross profit increased by 24% year-over-year, and earnings per share exceeded analysts' expectations. At the same time, Dorsey announced layoffs of over 4,000 employees, representing 46% of the company's total workforce. Following the announcement, Block's stock price rose 24% in after-hours trading. The company's performance increased by 24%, the stock price increased by 24%, and then 4,000 people received resignation notices. Citrini's "2028 nightmare" didn't even reach 2028; it began its first act this Thursday.

We are not in trouble

In history, every large-scale layoff has been accompanied by a set formula in the CEO's open letter:The market environment is severe, and we have made a difficult decision due to adjustments in our strategic direction. We thank every colleague for their contributions.

Dorsey's letter is different. "We're not in trouble. Our business is strong‚Ä¶ but something has changed. We've seen internally that smaller teams are doing more and better, working with the smart tools we're building and using. And the capabilities of these tools are compounding every week." There's no mention of a market downturn; the company is doing great, but you don't need them anymore. This candor is unsettling. Past layoff narratives always included an implicit promise: we'll rehire once the market improves. This time, Dorsey didn't even make that promise. He offered a different logic: A small team plus AI can do the same things as a large team, or even better. If that's the case, why are so many people needed? Investors completely agreed with this logic, voting with a 24% increase in the stock price. There's another detail that might have been overlooked. To promote an "AI-first" work culture, Dorsey previously required every employee in the company to send him a weekly email listing five recently completed tasks. Thousands of emails flooded in, and Dorsey's approach was to use AI to summarize them and then read the summaries. Using AI to determine who can prove they won't be replaced by AI, and letting AI analyze who will be laid off‚Äîthis detail is the most precise metaphor in the whole story. A timeline, an acceleration. Block isn't an isolated case; it's a trend that has been running for two years. Looking back, the acceleration of this trajectory is dazzling. In 2024, Klarna CEO Sebastian Siemiatkowski announced that the company's AI customer service assistant handled the equivalent of 700 full-time employees' workload. At the time, most people saw it as a tech show; the CEO needed headline-grabbing numbers and a story to convince investors. In April 2025, an internal memo from Shopify CEO Tobi L√ºtke was leaked. One sentence in the memo, which has since been repeatedly quoted, stated: "Before requesting additional staff, the team must first prove that AI cannot do this." That same year, Duolingo announced its "AI-first" strategy, terminating a large number of content creation outsourcing contracts. IBM admitted to replacing 8,000 HR positions with AI; CEO Arvind Krishna, in an interview, made no attempt to conceal this, directly naming the department and the number of people involved. Salesforce laid off 4,000 customer support positions, with CEO Marc Benioff stating, "AI can now handle about half of the company's work." By the end of 2025, data from Challenger, Gray & Christmas, a US employment tracking agency, showed that over 55,000 jobs were directly attributable to AI. At the beginning of 2026, Amazon announced two rounds of layoffs totaling approximately 30,000 corporate jobs. Law firm Baker McKenzie followed suit, laying off 600 to 1,000 research, marketing, and administrative support positions‚Äîan industry widely considered one of the most difficult for AI to penetrate. On February 26, 2026, in Block, a profitable company laid off 46% of its employees in one go. But layoffs are just the most visible weapon. A Harvard University study reveals a more insidious statistic: With the widespread adoption of AI, tech companies are hiring an average of five fewer junior employees per quarter. Without announcements or press releases, positions quietly disappear from job postings, and resumes submitted by recent graduates vanish without a trace; the reasons are never stated in rejection letters. Let's return to that viral article. Citrini's projections are unsettling not only because they depict a dystopian scenario of AI sweeping the job market, but also because they depict a logically consistent, perfectly rational death spiral. The spiral works like this: AI expands company profits. Funds from profit expansion were reinvested in AI, leading to even stronger AI capabilities. Stronger AI capabilities made more jobs replaceable. More unemployment meant less consumption. Shrinking consumption put pressure on more companies, forcing them to further reduce costs using AI. AI's capabilities advanced another step. Citrini named this cycle the Intelligence Displacement Spiral. They wrote in their article, "Individual decisions by each company are rational, but the collective result is disastrous." Now, let's look at what happened on Block. Gross profit rose 24%, stock price rose 24%, 4,000 people lost their jobs, and the money saved was reinvested in AI tools. From Dorsey's perspective, this was a completely rational decision. He even explained in an open letter why he chose a one-time large-scale layoff instead of multiple rounds of gradual reductions: because that would continuously damage morale and trust. From a corporate governance perspective, this is textbook-level execution. From the perspective of those 4,000 people, this is a disruption to their lives. In Citrini's deduction, there is a real person (presented anonymously): a friend who was a senior product manager at Salesforce, earning $180,000 a year, lost his job in the third round of layoffs in 2025. After searching for six months, he couldn't find a position at the same level. Finally, he started driving for Uber, and his annual income dropped to $45,000. This isn't just one person's story. Citrini, in her article, makes a simple multiplication: multiply this individual's trajectory by the hundreds of thousands of white-collar workers in major cities experiencing similar fates, and the decline in consumption ceases to be abstract macro data, but a predictable and calculable reality. This story is unfolding globally, perhaps even around us. Citrini's article states: "The historical disruption model posits that existing companies resist new technologies, ultimately allowing agile new entrants to erode their market share and lead to their demise. Kodak, Blockbuster, and BlackBerry are examples of this. However, the situation in 2026 is entirely different; existing companies are not resisting because they cannot afford the cost of resistance." This is the key to understanding the entire situation. Klarna was impacted by AI, and then used AI to cut costs, laying off a number of employees. Salesforce's software products were challenged by AI, and then AI replaced 4,000 customer service jobs. Block was hit by the AI ‚Äã‚Äãwave in the fintech industry, and then announced that it would restructure its entire organization with AI, laying off nearly half of its employees. These companies were not victims defeated by AI. They were the most active adopters of AI, and what was defeated were their own employees. This is the part that is hardest to deal with within a moral framework. After the 2008 financial crisis, people knew who to hate. Wall Street bankers, traders who packaged and sold junk bonds, and officials who failed to regulate. Anger had specific targets, even addresses, hence the Occupy Wall Street movement. This time is different. It's hard to say Dorsey did anything wrong. Block's stock price tells you what the market thinks. The 4,000 laid-off employees didn't do anything wrong either; they just happened to be working in roles that were being restructured. AI itself is certainly not a bad guy; it's just a tool that's becoming increasingly useful at a speed humans have never seen before. Responsibility permeates the entire system, like salt dissolving in water. You can taste the saltiness, but you can't find the grain of salt. Two sentences in Citrini's article, though not widely quoted, are perhaps the most profound: "For the first time in history, the most productive assets in the economy have created fewer, not more, jobs. No framework applies, because none of them were designed for a world where scarce factors of production have become abundant." After every technological revolution, humanity has found a new place. The steam engine replaced hand-weaving workers but created railway workers, factory managers, and urban planners. The internet eliminated travel agencies, physical record stores, and classified ads but invented product managers, data analysts, and content creators. Each time, those "jobs of the future" were initially indescribable, but they later emerged, and in enough numbers. This comforting rule has encountered a challenger for the first time. Because this time, AI itself is learning to do those "future jobs," such as AI trainers, AI prompt engineers, and AI product managers. The workers being replaced cannot simply "upgrade their skills" to AI-related positions because those positions themselves are being reduced. Harvard researchers have documented a phenomenon: After the widespread adoption of AI, entry-level job hiring at tech companies has decreased by more than 50%. This isn't because these positions have disappeared, but because they were never created in the first place. An entire generation is trained to enter an industry, and then, just as they're about to graduate, that industry quietly decides it no longer needs entry-level humans. We can't pretend we have time to figure things out. Citrini concludes by saying the canary is still alive, but the miner's problem is never whether the canary is dead or alive, but whether you have an exit when it starts to wobble.

data.title: Wintermute: Retail Trading of Cryptocurrencies and Stocks
data.description:
Author: Jasper De Maere, OTC Trader at Wintermute; Translator: Shaw, Jinse Finance

Retail activity influences the cryptocurrency market. Through speculation, buying on dips, and flexible fund rotation in the token space, retail investors dominate every major cycle. Recent data shows that the relationship between retail investors and cryptocurrencies is changing.

We have noticed that retail investors' attention has shifted from altcoins to the stock market for some time now. New data from JPMorgan Strategy, combined with our proprietary flow data, now shows that stocks and cryptocurrencies are emerging as alternative risk assets.

The Reversal of Relationship

By overlaying Wintermute's proprietary cryptocurrency retail flow data with JPMorgan's retail equity inflow data, we can observe the relationship between retail stock and cryptocurrency trading activity from a new perspective.

Historically, until the end of 2024, the two markets moved largely in tandem. At that time, heightened risk appetite led investors to buy both stocks and cryptocurrencies, as both served to some extent to release excess capital (such as broad money supply M2) and alleviate risk aversion. However, since the end of 2024, this relationship has broken down, and the two markets are now diverging at their greatest extent ever, with retail investors flooding into the stock market at a record pace while remaining on the sidelines regarding the cryptocurrency market.

When we broaden our perspective, we use altcoin market capitalization as a long-term measure of retail investor cryptocurrency activity. It is closely correlated with our retail fund flow data and has a longer-term, more objective historical data. From 2022 to the end of 2024, cryptocurrencies and stocks moved roughly in tandem, both considered a collection of high-risk investments by retail investors. This decoupling was particularly pronounced at the end of 2024, with retail activity becoming more driven by short-term factors, more volatile, and less structured.

... The rolling correlation between retail activity and altcoin market capitalization confirms this shift. The previously volatile but generally positive correlation has turned negative. Retail investors are now allocating between the two, rather than investing in both simultaneously.

Broadening the perspective to 2025 and combining it with key driving factors can make market dynamics clearer. The following points are particularly noteworthy:

  • When stock market activity stagnates and retail investors turn to other speculative areas, Meme coin and AI agents have a golden opportunity for development. Retail investors have been actively buying stocks on dips, both before and after the April 2025 tariff announcement and more recently. Since October 10th, funds have almost entirely shifted to the stock market, and this trend continues. It's worth noting that we believe the scale of retail trading activity in cryptocurrencies is not yet sufficient to draw funds away from the stock market. Our view is that increased retail trading activity in the stock market is draining funds from the cryptocurrency market. This new data also confirms this. Retail trading activity in the stock market is a new factor that cryptocurrency investors should closely monitor to capitalize on opportunities when cryptocurrencies can generate more sustained buying interest from retail investors.

    Volatility is a Selling Point

    While there are many reasons, one of the reasons why retail investors are so active in the cryptocurrency market and attracted to it is the asset's volatility. Volatility itself is a selling point of cryptocurrencies and a fundamental reason that attracts retail investors to the cryptocurrency space. Although the actual volatility of cryptocurrencies still far exceeds that of the stock market, its actual volatility has been declining, and this trend is unlikely to reverse. The Bitcoin/Nasdaq volatility ratio (BTC/NDX) has continued to decline, even compressing to below 2x in the first half of 2025. Thoughts on some key driving factors: The market is maturing. With the increasing number of sophisticated investors and the emergence of new liquidity instruments such as ETFs and DATs, the sharp fluctuations commonly seen in previous cycles have diminished. Market Size. Even with a market capitalization of only $2.3 trillion, down 40% from its all-time high, the amount of capital required to shake the market is far greater than it was five years ago. As volatility narrows, the core selling point of cryptocurrencies for retail investors is also weakening. The massive swings that once defined the 2021-2022 cycle and attracted a generation of retail investors are no longer present. For retail investors chasing volatility, stocks are becoming increasingly attractive. Technology Drivers. Beyond the market structure unique to cryptocurrencies, technology drivers are accelerating this shift, a point that hasn't received enough discussion. Cryptocurrency Access‚ÄîThe integration of cryptocurrency trading into fintech and traditional brokerage platforms (or the integration of stock trading into cryptocurrency-native platforms) lowers the barriers to entry, but its more significant impact lies in exit mechanisms. In the past, cumbersome entry processes made it difficult to transfer funds once invested in the cryptocurrency market, leading to a natural circulation of funds between different tokens. Now, these convenient inflow/outflow channels allow funds to flow easily between cryptocurrencies and stocks with virtually no obstacles. Advantages‚ÄîRetail investors seem increasingly inclined towards stocks, partly due to the new sense of superiority brought by artificial intelligence. Large Language Models (LLMs) significantly enhance the analytical capabilities of retail investors, creating a level playing field. This sense of superiority doesn't exist in the cryptocurrency space. While cryptocurrencies can be analyzed based on data, the lack of a consensus valuation framework and token value accumulation, coupled with the ever-expanding scope of investment, makes it difficult for retail investors to gain that sense of advantage. Conclusion: Retail investors were once the most reliable source of reflexive demand for cryptocurrencies, but today they increasingly seek risk appetite in other areas. The stock market offers increasing volatility, is more competitive, has a growing analytical advantage, and retail investors can easily switch from cryptocurrencies to stocks using their existing applications. Cryptocurrencies still hold a place in retail portfolios, but they are now just one of many investment tools, not the primary speculative instrument. This shift should also affect how investors view the market. Some previously effective indicators have become ineffective. For cryptocurrency investors, simply finding leading indicators of risk appetite and combining them with the native framework of cryptocurrencies is no longer sufficient to achieve success. Investors increasingly need to view cryptocurrencies from a multi-asset portfolio perspective, just as they would with stocks and fixed-income products‚Äîthis has become standard practice.

data.title: MrBeast Video Editor Suspended By Beast Industries After Near-Perfect Trades Flagged By Kalshi

A video editor for the global YouTube sensation MrBeast has been suspended from his role following allegations of insider trading on the prediction platform Kalshi.

The fallout began when Kalshi identified "near-perfect" trading patterns from an account linked to Artem Kaptur, an editor for the channel.

The platform determined that Kaptur likely leveraged his access to unreleased video content to place successful wagers on specific outcomes within MrBeast‚Äôs high-stakes challenges.

data.title: Why did Bitcoin prices fall along with software stocks?
data.description:
Author: Anthony Pompliano, Founder and CEO of Professional Capital Management

Over the past few weeks, investors have been most focused on the rapid sell-off in software stocks. To better understand why, I asked Silvia (our AI-driven CFO) for an explanation. Here's what she said:

  • This sell-off, dubbed the "SaaS doomsday," has wiped out more than $1 trillion in market capitalization from software stocks since late January 2026. The primary driver is a sudden and intense investor concern: the emergence of artificial intelligence, particularly autonomous AI agents (such as Anthropic's Claude Cowork), is poised to disrupt the traditional SaaS business model. Investors worry that if AI tools can replace the entire software workflow‚Äîfrom coding to customer service to IT management‚Äîthe seat-based subscription model that has underpinned SaaS valuations for a decade will be fundamentally threatened. According to USA Today and Reuters, the iShares Technology Software ETF (IGV) has fallen approximately 20% year-to-date, with major companies suffering heavy losses: Microsoft is down about 28% from its peak, Oracle is down about 55%, Salesforce is down about 30%, and Adobe is down about 27%. Adding to the woes, the sector is experiencing a massive rotation. Funds are flowing out of traditional SaaS companies and into AI infrastructure companies, value stocks, and industrial sectors. Despite largely stable fundamentals, the software sector's forward price-to-earnings ratio has compressed from approximately 39 times to 21 times, falling to a multi-year low. According to AInvest data, all software companies in the S&P 500 that reported earnings beat expectations last quarter, with 80% exceeding revenue expectations. Companies like ServiceNow and AppLovin reported record earnings, but their share prices still suffered heavy losses because Wall Street's focus has shifted from current profitability to ultimate value‚Äîessentially questioning whether these established companies can survive in a world of autonomous AI agents. JPMorgan Chase called the sell-off driven by "logical inconsistencies," believing the market is digesting a worst-case scenario that hasn't yet occurred. These are significant promises that short sellers rely on to support their investment logic. The sudden and significant reduction in the market capitalization of all software companies compared to just a few weeks ago is truly perplexing.

    Silvia then explained the crux of the debate: Is this an overreaction by investors, or a structural turning point in the market?

    ... "Short sellers argue that AI agents will commoditize software, squeeze profit margins, and erode the user base‚Äîsome analysts at Bain and Forrester point out that CIOs are consolidating software budgets and reallocating spending to AI tools rather than expanding SaaS reach. Bulls counter that deeply embedded 'record systems' platforms (like Salesforce, ServiceNow, and Intuit) have a sticky customer base and recurring revenue that won't disappear overnight, making their current valuations potentially an attractive entry point. The truth may lie somewhere in between‚ÄîAI will reshape the industry, but this indiscriminate sell-off has depressed the stock prices of many quality companies as if their businesses were already on the decline, a conclusion the data doesn't yet support." One question I've been pondering is the relationship between software stocks and Bitcoin. If software stocks are falling due to concerns about artificial intelligence, why is Bitcoin falling at the same time? Are investors genuinely worried that AI will impact Bitcoin's future? Silvia explains this clearly: "In early 2026, the correlation between Bitcoin and software stocks surged to astonishing levels. As of February, Bitcoin's 30-day rolling correlation with the iShares Extended Technology Software ETF (IGV) reached 0.73, a very high figure. Bitcoin's correlation with the Nasdaq 100 also jumped from -0.68 to +0.72 in just a few weeks. Meanwhile, its correlation with gold was only 0.12. In effect, Bitcoin traded more like a high-beta software stock than a safe-haven asset." The mechanism driving this correlation is institutional fund flows, not fundamental overlap. Since the launch of spot Bitcoin ETFs in early 2024, Bitcoin has increasingly been included in institutional portfolios alongside growth and tech stocks. When risk aversion events occur‚Äîsuch as the sell-off in AI-driven software stocks triggered by the launch of Anthropic's Claude Cowork‚Äîportfolio managers broadly reduce risk, selling both software stocks and Bitcoin. At the peak of the sell-off, Bitcoin ETFs experienced average daily outflows of $272 million, with cumulative outflows from cryptocurrency products reaching $1.7 billion. This is not a phenomenon unique to cryptocurrencies‚Äîit's a broader risk aversion mechanism where funds shift from growth assets to gold, government bonds, and cash. Bitcoin, as a risk-averse asset, is also held by these institutions and is therefore affected by this countercurrent. The key nuance‚Äîand what makes this particularly tricky‚Äîlies in the negative skewness of Bitcoin's correlation with its price. Bitcoin falls much more sharply than it rises with software stocks. When IGV rises, Bitcoin's reaction is relatively muted; conversely, when IGV falls, Bitcoin tends to amplify the decline. This asymmetry exacerbates the situation‚ÄîBitcoin bears the risk of a decline in its correlation with tech stocks but fails to fully participate in their rallies. Stifel even predicts Bitcoin could fall to $38,000, pointing out that its 0.78 correlation with the Nasdaq 100 suggests that Bitcoin is now more like a leveraged bet on tech stocks than a safe-haven asset for the dollar. Clearly, the current sell-off is highly correlated. The most likely scenario for this correlation to disappear is that institutional investors no longer view Bitcoin as a growth/risk asset. As long as Bitcoin remains in the same category as software stocks in institutional portfolios and is influenced by the same macroeconomic factors (Fed policy, liquidity, risk appetite), it will continue to trade like leveraged tech stocks. To change this, a large number of marginal buyers of Bitcoin need to shift from momentum-chasing hedge funds and ETF-driven retail investors to structural, price-insensitive holders‚Ä¶ primarily those who adhere to long-term holdings regardless of quarterly macroeconomic changes. The most likely catalyst is widespread adoption by sovereign nations. The United States has established a strategic Bitcoin reserve using seized assets, while countries like Brazil, El Salvador, and Bhutan are exploring or actively accumulating Bitcoin as a sovereign reserve. For the first time since 1996, central bank gold reserves have surpassed foreign holdings of US Treasury bonds, potentially representing a structural "sovereign asset rotation" from which Bitcoin could benefit if it ultimately proves to be a reliable neutral reserve asset. If major central banks (especially sovereign wealth funds) begin actively purchasing Bitcoin, this will create a large, price-insensitive demand base, absorbing selling pressure during periods of heightened risk aversion and fundamentally reducing its correlation with stocks. Gold's trajectory is largely consistent with this, and Bitcoin aspires to follow a similar path. The decoupling of Bitcoin from software stocks will be a multi-year process. This requires a gradual shift in the Bitcoin holder base from speculative/institutional investors to sovereign/structural investors, reduced volatility, and at least one crisis where Bitcoin doesn't sell off along with all other assets. The sovereign reserve trend is currently the most promising catalyst, but as long as exchange-traded fund (ETF)-driven institutional flows dominate Bitcoin's marginal pricing, it will still behave like an extension of the high-beta growth/tech sector during periods of market stress. Therefore, one way to understand Bitcoin's current correlation is that this asset is a victim of its own success. What we want is mainstream acceptance, and we have achieved that, but this mainstream acceptance (especially on Wall Street) has had side effects. The new correlation with software stocks is the most obvious example. Bitcoin is definitely fine. I expect it to continue to perform well in the future. The challenge for you as investors is to avoid getting bored. Good luck.

As of February 2026, the U.S. government held approximately 328,372 Bitcoins, representing approximately 1.64% of the global circulating supply (approximately 19.9 million Bitcoins). Based on current market prices, the value exceeds $20 billion. With this scale, the United States becomes the world's largest holder of Bitcoin, far exceeding any other government. Almost all of these Bitcoins came from law enforcement seizures, not from government appropriations or market purchases. While cracking down on the illicit uses of Bitcoin, the United States has quietly transformed these "criminal assets" into a national strategic reserve. Looking back at the US law enforcement and regulatory actions surrounding cryptocurrencies over the past decade, from cracking down on dark web markets to on-chain tracking and cross-border collaboration, it's clear that the US has never truly intended to "eliminate" Bitcoin. Instead, it has focused on controlling its flow and use, incorporating it into national strategic reserves, and forming a closed loop that integrates technology, law, and assets.

Timeline: Landmark Actions in the US Hunt for Bitcoin

2011-2013

2013-2014Year: The Hunting of Multiple Dark Web Markets and the Laying of a Regulatory Framework

After the Silk Road ended, the United States did not stop. On March 18, 2013, FinCEN (Financial Crimes Enforcement Network) issued guidance classifying Bitcoin exchanges and similar services as "money services businesses". The requirement for registration and implementation of KYC/AML (Know Your Customer) anti-money laundering mechanisms (MBL) by the US (Manufacturing Transaction Management System) marked the true beginning of the US Bitcoin regulatory framework, forcing exchanges to comply with regulations. In November 2014, the FBI, along with Europol and law enforcement agencies from 17 countries, launched Operation Onymous, simultaneously shutting down over 400 [unclear - possibly related to security measures]. The dark web market includes major drug and counterfeit money laundering sites such as Silk Road 2.0, Cloud 9, and Hydra. The key weapon at this stage is the "civil forfeiture" system, which allows assets to be frozen with only a preponderance of evidence and without criminal conviction. The U.S. Marshals Service subsequently began regularly auctioning off confiscated Bitcoin. In 2014, investor Tim Draper participated in the auction, becoming one of the early public buyers. With a two-pronged approach of crackdown and compliance, Bitcoin was pulled from the underground into the regulatory order. 2017-2018: ICO Bubble Burst and Securities Regulation. After the ICO craze swept the globe, US regulators began a systematic cleanup. The SEC considers a large number of ICOs as ‚Äúunregistered securities‚Äù and initiates enforcement actions against the project teams; the CFTC, on the other hand, has confirmed that Bitcoin is a ‚Äúcommodity‚Äù. The government has incorporated these regulations into its own oversight. Administrative fines, asset freezes, and litigation threats have been implemented. Centralized projects are forced to comply with regulations, reshaping the industry's financing model. While decentralized systems have gained room for development, compliance costs have increased significantly. 2020: The Aftermath of the Silk Road The 2012-2013 Silk Road hacking incident. This operation spanned seven years. Law enforcement used on-chain analytics tools such as Chainalysis and TRM Labs to track the flow of cold wallets through cluster analysis and transaction pattern matching, completing civil seizures without the need for private keys.

 As early as 2012, during the Silk Road era, Zhong used a fake merchant account to exploit a vulnerability in "Instant Withdrawal" to steal approximately 50,000 Bitcoins within a few days. In April 2024, Zhao Changpeng was sentenced to four months in prison and served his sentence. In October 2025, President Trump announced a pardon for him. 2025: A Strategic Shift and the Largest Confiscation in History If the actions of the previous decade or so were a process of hunting down and purging, then 2025 saw a directional shift. On March 6, 2025, Trump signed an executive order establishing the Strategic Bitcoin Reserve and the U.S. Digital Asset Reserve. Previously, all Bitcoins seized by law enforcement would no longer be auctioned off, but instead become long-term national reserve assets and could not be sold. The policy logic has thus been rewritten, shifting from "post-crackdown auction for monetization" to "zero-cost strategic holding". On October 14th, the U.S. Department of Justice imposed sanctions on Chinese citizens of Cambodia's Prince Group. The China National Computer Virus Emergency Response Center released a technical tracing report, pointing out that a large-scale Bitcoin theft occurred at LuBian's mining pool in 2020, with the amount highly consistent with the scale of this seizure, and raising technical questions about the acquisition method. This incident is not only an unprecedented seizure of virtual assets, but also a landmark case of the intertwined struggle between law enforcement power, technical capabilities, and narrative power in the digital asset field. Concurrently, the Russian-operated Garantex exchange and its successor, Grinex, have been accused of providing money laundering channels for sanctioned countries' hacking and fraud, and have continued to face sanctions and infrastructure attacks. The interplay between on-chain tracking, pressure on the dollar clearing system, and control of physical servers systematically demonstrates cross-border law enforcement capabilities. After being placed on the sanctions list in early 2022, in March 2025, the U.S. Secret Service, in conjunction with German and Finnish law enforcement agencies, seized its domain name and froze approximately $26 million in assets; the Department of Justice indicted several executives, including Aleksej Besciokov, who was arrested in India; In August, the U.S. Treasury Department further expanded the scope of sanctions against OFAC, and the State Department offered a reward of up to $5 million for the capture of those responsible. With this, the U.S. has completed a closed loop in its handling of crypto assets, enabling it to both suppress, freeze, and confiscate them, as well as hold them long-term and incorporate them into national reserves. From technological suppression to asset integration, Bitcoin has been incorporated into the national strategic framework. From Hunting to Nationalization The United States' approach to Bitcoin has shifted from viewing it as a tool to combating crime to incorporating it as a national strategic asset. It's not just about law enforcement and regulation of cryptocurrencies; it's about achieving control over the entire Bitcoin supply chain and integrating national interests through a high degree of synergy between technology, law, and strategic reserves. Leveraging its globally leading on-chain tracing technology, national-level cyberattack capabilities, and transnational collaboration, the United States has constructed a three-pronged closed loop of "technological advantage‚Äîregulatory binding‚Äîinstitutional enforcement," making Bitcoin a crucial component of its financial resilience and international dominance.

1.¬†Technical Aspect

The United States, relying on its globally leading on-chain tracing technology, national-level cyber attack capabilities, and transnational cooperation, has achieved precise control over the entire Bitcoin chain. On-chain traceability capabilities: The United States possesses the world's most advanced on-chain traceability technology, with leading US companies such as Chainalysis and Elliptic holding over 90% of the market share. The above market share allows for clustering and tracking of over 99% of Bitcoin transactions. Even using CoinJoin or mixers, on/off-ramp (fiat currency inflows and outflows) often exposes address associations. Combining Physics and Law: Without cracking private keys, hardware wallets, exchange accounts, or cloud storage files can be directly controlled through search warrants or court orders. In the Chen Zhi case, 25 cold wallet addresses were precisely located; in the Bitfinex case, direct control of assets was achieved by obtaining private keys through cloud storage. National-level cyberattack capabilities: The United States has launched targeted attacks against global exchanges and mining pools, including backdoor implantation, spear-phishing, supply chain infiltration, and exploitation of underlying encryption vulnerabilities. The LuBian mining pool case exploited the weakness of pseudo-random numbers, precisely transferring over 127,000 Bitcoins within 2 hours, demonstrating technological dominance. International Cooperation and Long-Arm Jurisdiction: Sharing intelligence with the EU, the UK, etc., and imposing sanctions on companies like OFAC, Tornado Cash, and Garantex, combined with dollar clearing hegemony, domain name seizures, and transnational arrests, to form a global hunting network and achieve full-chain control of digital assets. 2. Legal and Institutional Levels The United States, through legal systems and technological cooperation, has incorporated Bitcoin into its national control system, providing a solid guarantee for its strategic reserves. The GENIUS Act requires stablecoin issuers to use over 80% of their reserve assets to purchase U.S. Treasury bonds, creating sustained demand for U.S. Treasury bonds and binding the crypto ecosystem to the dollar system. The BITCOIN Act establishes the link between virtual assets and the U.S. financial system, clarifies civil forfeiture mechanisms, and provides legal support for the transfer of assets to state ownership. Civil confiscation: Assets can be seized without criminal conviction, resulting in extremely high efficiency. From 2022 to 2025, the United States confiscated over $30 billion worth of virtual assets globally through various cases, with the Chen Zhi case alone accounting for 50%. This synergy between law and technology forms a complete closed loop of "rule pre-setting ‚Äî technology forensics ‚Äî asset harvesting," providing institutional guarantees for strategic reserves. 3. Strategic Reserve Approach The US's handling of Bitcoin reflects a complete evolution from precise targeting to systematic harvesting, and finally to its inclusion in national strategic reserves. Through a high degree of synergy in technology, regulations, and international cooperation, the US has established full-chain control over global virtual assets. Its methods include: precise monitoring and control of transactions using on-chain tracking technology and state-level cyberattack capabilities; direct transfer of assets through court orders and civil forfeiture; and forming a global encirclement loop through cooperation with allies, OFAC sanctions, domain name seizures, and transnational law enforcement. Case studies demonstrate the high efficiency of this capability: in the Chen Zhi case, confiscated assets were directly placed under state control; in the Zhao Changpeng case, through rule-based export and technological tracking, the United States rapidly transformed cross-border assets into strategic reserves. This strategy allows the United States to incorporate seized assets into its national reserves without requiring market purchases, using Bitcoin as a hedge against inflation and volatility in the dollar system, essentially as "digital gold." As of February 2026, the United States held approximately 328,372 Bitcoins, representing 1.64% of the global circulating supply, with a value exceeding $20 billion, almost entirely from confiscation operations. On March 6, 2025, the United States signed an executive order entitled "Establishing a Strategic Bitcoin Reserve and a U.S. Digital Asset Reserve," officially designating Bitcoin as a strategic reserve asset and requiring the Treasury Department to cease auctioning and selling Bitcoin obtained through judicial seizures and to transfer it to a newly established strategic reserve account. Although the BITCOIN Act recommended purchasing 1 million tokens over five years, this has not yet been implemented; the executive order only authorizes a potential strategy of "budget neutrality and no additional taxpayer costs." Open market purchases have not been implemented, nor has any explicit commitment been made. Overall, the United States' strategy is highly systematic, neither completely eliminating nor completely abandoning Bitcoin, thus achieving precise control and strategic utilization. From a tool of crime in the "Silk Road" era to a core asset of national strategic reserves, the evolution of Bitcoin reflects a new landscape of national technological hegemony in the digital age, strengthening the United States' dominance in the global digital financial system and profoundly impacting technological sovereignty, economic interests, and political security.

data.title: Whose fig leaf did ZachXBT just tear off?
data.description:
An anonymous investigator with a cartoon platypus head could trigger a panic-driven self-investigation of the entire crypto industry with just a single teaser tweet‚Äîthis isn't science fiction, but a real industry earthquake that occurred in February 2026. On February 24, 2026, renowned blockchain detective ZachXBT posted a short teaser on the X platform: "On February 26th, I will expose one of the most profitable companies in the crypto industry, whose multiple employees have been using insider information for large-scale insider trading." This tweet quickly garnered 8 million views and 27,000 likes, setting a new personal record for him. The market reaction was far more intense than anticipated. The prediction market Polymarket quickly launched a contract predicting which company ZachXBT would expose for insider trading, with total trading volume soaring to over $30 million. The Solana ecosystem protocol Meteora was initially considered the prime suspect with a 48% probability. The entire crypto community descended into a game of fear and intrigue, searching for the "insider." This precisely exposes a harsh reality within the crypto industry: insider trading is not an isolated phenomenon, but a systemic problem. When a mere mention of a platypus can send shivers down the spine of the entire industry, we are compelled to ask: Whose veil has ZachXBT lifted?

01 Detective and Prey: An Asymmetrical War of Transparency

To understand the industry earthquake triggered by ZachXBT, we must first recognize the unique position of this "on-chain Sherlock Holmes." This retail investor, who lost $15,000 in a 2018 wallet hack and subsequently taught himself blockchain analysis, has now become one of the most feared investigative forces in the crypto world.

ZachXBT's working methods embody the paradox of blockchain technology's transparency. He utilizes fully public on-chain data‚Äîtransaction flows, wallet clusters, mixer models‚Äîcombined with traditional open-source intelligence gathering to construct a convincing chain of evidence. His past achievements include: directly recovering $210 million in stolen funds, assisting in the arrest of suspects related to the Terra crash, and exposing more than 25 attacks by the North Korean hacking group Lazarus Group.

The narrative of "one man against the entire dark forest" holds true because of the regulatory vacuum in the crypto industry. Traditional financial markets have regulatory bodies like the SEC and CFTC, with clear definitions and legal consequences for insider trading. In the crypto world, however, the gap between regulatory lag and the speed of technological innovation creates enormous arbitrage opportunities. ZachXBT's influence is essentially a form of "alternative regulation." While formal regulatory bodies are still trying to understand the basic concepts of blockchain, this anonymous detective has already conducted enforcement actions using code and data analysis. His presence has changed industry behavior‚Äîfraudsters now know that transferring stolen funds could be the start of a public investigation. 02 Under the Fig Leaf: The Three Masks of Insider Trading ZachXBT's investigation announcement triggered industry-wide panic because it touched on the three most sensitive nerves regarding insider trading in the crypto industry. **First Mask: Exchange Employees' "Information Privileges"**. This model is considered classic insider trading in traditional financial markets, but it has long existed in a gray area in the crypto world. Exchanges play the dual role of referee and player, giving their employees far more access to core data than traditional brokerages. **Second Mask: Market Makers' "Algorithmic Manipulation"**. Almost simultaneously with the ZachXBT investigation, Wall Street quantitative giant Jane Street is facing insider trading allegations. The lawsuit alleges that Jane Street employees obtained non-public information about Terraform Labs' liquidity operations through a private chat group called "Bryce's Secret." On May 7, 2022, less than ten minutes after Terraform Labs withdrew $150 million of UST from Curve 3pool, wallets associated with Jane Street withdrew $85 million of UST, directly accelerating UST's de-anchoring and the evaporation of $40 billion in market value. Even more disturbingly, Jane Street was accused of running a "10 AM crash algorithm." Blockchain analysts discovered that throughout 2025, Bitcoin experienced a sudden sell-off every trading day at 10 AM Eastern Time (coinciding with the opening time of the US stock market), triggering leveraged long liquidations followed by a rapid price rebound. After Jane Street was sued, this pattern abruptly stopped, and Bitcoin saw its largest single-day gain in months. The third mask: "Legitimized insider trading" in prediction markets. The frenzied betting on ZachXBT investigation subjects on Polymarket is itself an irony of the industry's current state. Users are attempting to "trade insider information about insider trading investigations." This is not an isolated case: in December 2025, multiple accounts accurately bet on the week before OpenAI released GPT-5.2, profiting over $13,000; one account profited $1 million in a single day by betting on Google search data. In January 2026, a new account placed a $30,000 bet before Maduro was detained and profited $400,000 within 24 hours. Polymarket's rules actually encourage betting based on private information, arguing that this reflects market efficiency. However, when this "efficiency" is built on information asymmetry, it is essentially a variant of insider trading. 03 Systemic Disease: Why is Insider Trading So Difficult to Eradicate in the Crypto Industry? The rampant insider trading in the crypto industry is not accidental, but a systemic disease determined by its underlying logic and current stage of development. The conflict between technological transparency and human greed is the fundamental contradiction. Blockchain technology is inherently transparent; every transaction is recorded on a public ledger. However, this technological transparency does not automatically translate into behavioral transparency. Instead, it creates the illusion that since everything is on-chain, there should be no black box operations. The reality is quite the opposite‚Äîtransparent data requires professional interpretation, and the right to interpret it often resides in the hands of a few. The business model of regulatory arbitrage fuels this phenomenon. Many crypto companies headquartered in jurisdictions with lax regulations, exploiting differences in regulatory standards across countries for arbitrage. Jane Street was fined $560 million in India for cross-market manipulation, but this did not deter similar activities in other markets. The culture of early, unregulated growth in the industry has not completely faded. From its inception, the crypto industry has been strongly anti-establishment and anti-regulatory; the concept of "code is law" was initially simplified to "no law." Although mainstream institutions are entering the market, the cultural inertia of profiting from information asymmetry remains strong. The difficulty of investigating complex violations further complicates the issue. Insider trading in the crypto industry is often intertwined with other violations such as market manipulation, money laundering, and fraud. As the Jane Street case illustrates, insider trading accelerated market crashes, which in turn created new opportunities for manipulation. This "illegal ecosystem" makes investigation and evidence collection exceptionally difficult.

04 Traditional vs. Crypto: The "Evolution" of Insider Trading

Comparing insider trading models in traditional and crypto finance reveals some disturbing "evolutionary" trends.

Anonymity shifts from interpersonal networks to technological networks. Traditional insider trading relies on offline communication such as phone calls and meetings, while insider information in the crypto world can be instantly transmitted globally through encrypted chat software and dark web forums. Jane Street's "Bryce's Secret" Telegram group is a typical example.

Operational methods shift from manual decision-making to algorithmic execution. Traditional insider traders need to place orders manually, while crypto market makers can write algorithms to automatically execute insider trading strategies.

Operational methods shift from manual decision-making to algorithmic execution. If the allegations against Jane Street regarding the "10 AM crash algorithm" are true, it represents an extreme case of algorithmic insider trading. The impact has shifted from localized markets to global reach. Traditional insider trading typically affects a single market or asset, but the 24/7 global trading nature of the crypto market allows its effects to instantly impact investors worldwide. The Terra crash wiped out $40 billion in market capitalization, with victims across the globe. Regulatory arbitrage has shifted from geographical avoidance to technological avoidance. Traditional financial institutions evade regulation by registering in tax havens, while crypto companies leverage the anonymity and cross-border nature of blockchain to create a more sophisticated form of regulatory arbitrage. 05 Behind the Fig Leaf: What Kind of Transparency Revolution Does the Industry Need? ZachXBT's investigation acts as a mirror, reflecting the truth the crypto industry least wants to face. The issue isn't whether insider trading exists, but whether the industry is prepared for a genuine revolution in transparency. Technological transparency is not ethical transparency‚Äîthis is the first lesson the industry must learn. Blockchain can ensure the immutability of transaction data, but it cannot guarantee the purity of transaction motives. The industry needs to establish ethical standards that go beyond code. The paradox of decentralized ideals requiring centralized accountability urgently needs to be resolved. The crypto world champions decentralization, but effective regulation requires a clearly defined accountable body. How to maintain the advantages of decentralization while establishing an effective governance structure is key to the industry's maturity. Regulatory innovation must keep pace with technological innovation. Traditional financial regulatory frameworks, built on paper transactions and T+2 settlements, are completely unsuitable for the real-time and global nature of the crypto world. Regulators need to learn, like ZachXBT, to use blockchain tools to regulate the blockchain world. Investor education needs to shift from "get-rich-quick myths" to "risk awareness." Too many investors are attracted by high returns but lack basic understanding of systemic risks such as insider trading and market manipulation. The industry has a responsibility to provide more comprehensive risk disclosure. ZachXBT's platypus icon cast a shadow over the crypto world that is far longer than many are willing to admit. The market panic triggered by his investigative announcements was not fear of a specific company, but a collective anxiety about the ethical bottom line of the entire industry. When Polymarket users frantically bet on who the next "mole" will be, when Jane Street's algorithm is accused of regularly dumping tokens and profiting from retail investors, when exchange employees use listing information for personal gain‚Äîthese are not isolated incidents, but different symptoms of the same disease. The disease is called structural information asymmetry, and the cure is called systemic transparency. The veil lifted by ZachXBT exposes not just a few bad apples, but an entire orchard in dire need of overhaul. The crypto industry stands at a crossroads: will it continue its unchecked growth in a regulatory vacuum, ultimately self-destructing due to a collapse in trust; or will it proactively embrace a revolution in transparency, establishing a trustworthy new financial paradigm? The answer will determine whether this industry becomes the hope for financial democratization or merely a speculative casino of Wall Street 2.0. And time is ticking away.
